item.content:encoded:
Thanks to Karel (et al) for tons of hard work which resulted in the biggest and brightest EuRuKo yet, fantastic. Thanks to MATZ and all participants and attendees - Ruby’s lifeblood.

Next stop …2009 !

  • MADRID ?
  • KRAKOW ?
  • OTHERS ?

(Post any suggestions/votes at the open facebook group called “EURUKOBACKWEB”)

LET’S GATHER in those suggestions for the next great “European Ruby Konference” venue … but remember … we really need a big (cheap or even free) venue, maybe another University lecture hall and above all a “great organiser” to champion it … and of course keep the entry fee steady at a loving 20 Euro.

We all want EuRuKo 2009 to be serious FUN.
Target dates should be carefuly suggested to not clash with other big Ruby events (or even other OO / Rails / Python / OS ..) and better avoiding Easter too ! Spring is a good season though…so we should plan for March/April 2009 …

My guess is …Ruby just hit the exp curve, this is PrimeTime !

What do you say ?

item.title: Ruby is … EXTENSIBLE
item.dc:creator: mikeleeeuropecom

item.content:encoded:
Recently, I was asked to speed up Ruby’s comparison of sorted integer arrays …containing upwards of 500,000 elements. Such arrays take up rather a lot of space in memory, so I’m happy I’ve got 2GB on my macbook handy.

First, I wanted to see how Ruby copes alone ! (She’s so brave and industrious !!)

So as a simple example, I created two arrays, namely “array_a” and “array_b”.

“array_a” contains all the numbers in-sequence from 1,2,3… upto 500,000

and “array_b” contains all the numbers in-sequence from 2,4,6… upto 1,000,000

So, armed with these two large sorted arrays (incidently, both containing only 500,000 elements) we can then ask Ruby questions..like:

Hey Ruby, how many elements are common to both array_a and array_b ?

I know…lets ask her to make the arrays aswell… (she’s so accomodating).

max_size = 500_000
array_a = []
array_b = []
for i in 0..max_size-1
array_a[i] = i
array_b[i] = i*2
end

then we could ask ruby to tell us the number of common elements …

array_a&array_b.size

WOW, she’s so concise too!

In this example the two arrays perfectly intersect for even numbers only, so the answer should be 250,000. Try it …

—

Roll-your-own Ruby.

This is all fine we got our answer, but rather slowly and what if we wanted to go bigger and bigger, until we had billions of elements in our arrays.

Already, I could hear Ruby breathing heavily, she was designed for elegance and dainty high speed interaction working with people…not number crunching nuts and bolts like some old TPF mainframe compiler.

(Oh, the poor girl ! Somehow, I knew we had to save her from this heavy lifting!).

So, I offered to help Ruby out, by adding just one method to ease the grunt work.

The result was a Ruby extension in C for a method called “overlap” to do this intesection size checking a bit quicker…. here’s the quick answer of …

HOWTO create a C extension …
1 - Create a C file containing your new method and a few other bits

(I’ll post my file called “arrayOverlap.c” below)

2 - Create a Ruby file called “extconf.rb”, containing the following ruby code:

require ‘mkmf’
create_makefile(’arrayOverlap’)

3 - Ask Ruby to create the makefile by running “extconf.rb” (she’s great !)

4 - Type “make” at the command line

Done ! So, you’re now ready to use your new method just by requiring it :

require ‘arrayOverlap’

and to do some BENCHMARKING to see the improvement in speed!

Here’s a benchmarking comparison in Ruby… (and the C code follows it)

require ‘arrayOverlap’
require ‘benchmark’
require ‘pp’

obj = MyModule::MyClass.new

for i in 1..1 # use this loop with bigger values to “stress” test performance on your machine
# the arrays
max_loop = 5
max_size = 500_000
a = []
b = []
for i in 0..max_size-1
a[i] = i
b[i] = i*2
end

puts “a contains ” + a.size.to_s + ” elements.”
puts “b contains ” + b.size.to_s + ” elements.”

puts

# the benchmarking of C versus the Ruby versions
Benchmark.bmbm(10) do |x|
x.report(”R”) { for i in 1..max_loop; (a & b).size; end }
x.report(”C”) { for i in 1..max_loop; obj.overlap(a,b).to_s ; end }
end
puts
puts
end

puts “———————COUNT——————–”
puts “R said ” + (a & b).size.to_s + ” intersect.\n”
puts “C said ” + obj.overlap(a,b).to_s + ” intersect.\n”

puts “…Comparison Done”

and HERE’S that C code (shudder !!)

// file is called arrayOverlap.c

#include “ruby.h”

static int
intcmp(const void *v1, const void *v2)
{
return (*(int *)v1 - *(int *)v2);
}

int
binsearch(int key, int ary, int LEN2)
{
VALUE *ary2 = RARRAY(ary)->ptr;
int high, i, low;
for ( low=(-1), high=LEN2; high-low > 1; )
{
i = (high+low) / 2;
if ( key <= NUM2INT(ary2[i]) ) high = i;
else low = i;
}
if ( key==NUM2INT(ary2[high]) ) return( high );
else return( -1 );
}

VALUE
overlap(int argc, VALUE ary1, VALUE ary2)
{
VALUE count;
count = 0;
int i, LEN1, LEN2, sz, key, *pos;
VALUE *arr1 = RARRAY(ary1)->ptr;
VALUE *arr2 = RARRAY(ary2)->ptr;
LEN1 = RARRAY(ary1)->len;
LEN2 = RARRAY(ary2)->len;
key = NUM2INT(arr1[0]);
sz = sizeof(arr2[0]);
NUM2INT(arr2[i]));
for (i=0; i<LEN1; i++) {
key = NUM2INT(arr1[i]);
pos = binsearch(key, ary2, LEN2);
if (pos < -1) {
count = count + 1;
}
}
return INT2NUM(count);
}

// called by Ruby interpreter at load.
void Init_arrayOverlap()
{
VALUE myModule = rb_define_module(”MyModule”);
VALUE myClass = rb_define_class_under(myModule, “MyClass”, rb_cObject);
int arg_count = 2;
rb_define_method(myClass, “overlap”, overlap, arg_count);
}

// END OF ARRAY OVERLAP.C

Ruby is EXTENSIBLE !

item.content:encoded:
So, what’s all this about utility being part of love ? 

Well, Ruby first got her hooks into me by being so useful. Actually (IMHO), her utility is probably the best thing about her, she’s really great to have around. And, well, like “my dog”, “Swiss army knife” or “my towel” I feel more comfortable when I know she’s there.

(one should always know where one’s towel is!) 

Of course Ruby runs on many platforms, on Windows she’s only ever a “one-click-install” away http://rubyinstaller.rubyforge.org …  if you run a Mac or Linux, she’s already there, waiting for you !

You just need to call her name and ask for something:

  ruby say_hello.rb

She listens well and acts on your every word !

Which means that say_hello.rb needs to exist as a file or else she will reply something like:

  ruby: No such file or directory — say_hello.rb (LoadError)

So let’s create a file called say_hello.rb containing two lines of ruby script:
  name = “Beautiful”
  puts “Well, hello there #{name} !”

Now, we can ask Ruby to say hello again by typing:

  ruby say_hello.rb

She reponds:

  Well, hello there Beautiful !

Now you can see how very easy it is to get to like Ruby !

item.content:encoded:
Ruby is …

  • An easy to use programming language from Japan

  • FREE (as in ‘beer’ & as in ‘liberty’) 

  • Dynamic and extensible (many think it lovable too !)

  • Invented by Yukihiro Matsumoto (aka “Matz” )

Why blog about loving a  Computer Language ? 

Aristotle argues that there are three kinds of philia, for “not everything is loved, but [only] the lovable, and this is either good or pleasant or useful”. We can thus distinguish between:

  • Philia based on mutual advantage (love for what is useful).
  • Philia based on mutual pleasure (love for what is pleasant).
  • Philia based on mutual admiration (love for what is good).

Thus, I hope you will (or do) also find Ruby (www.ruby-lang.org) rather lovable, as it proves to be all three of the above … USEFUL, PLEASANT and GOOD. This blog seeks to present Ruby’s advantages, it’s pleasures and a general admiration of it and it’s community, the RubyPhiliacs.
